title: 113_s921
content:
The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2013" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2013" amends Section 30102(a) of title 49, United States Code by defining a "covered rental vehicle" as a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 10,000 pounds or less, rented without a driver for less than 4 months, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental purposes by a rental company. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2013" defines a "rental company" as a person engaged in renting 5 or more covered rental vehicles. SEC. 3. REMEDIES FOR DEFECTS AND NONCOMPLIANCE. Section 30120(i) of title 49, United States Code is amended to include rental vehicles. Notification requirements for rental companies are specified, allowing them to sell, lease, or rent covered vehicles. The amendment allows rental companies to offer vehicles for sale, lease, or rental within 24 hours of receiving notice to the owner. The rental company must comply with limitations on sale, lease, or rental within 48 hours of receiving a notice to the owner for more than 5,000 vehicles in its fleet. The rental company must comply with limitations on sale, lease, or rental within 48 hours of receiving a notice to the owner for more than 5,000 vehicles in its fleet. If a notification indicates that the remedy for a defect is not immediately available, the rental company can temporarily alter the vehicle to eliminate the safety risk and continue renting it. The rental company must comply with limitations on selling, leasing, or renting vehicles within 48 hours of receiving a notice for more than 5,000 vehicles. If a defect remedy is not available, the rental company can temporarily modify the vehicle to eliminate safety risks and continue renting it. The rental company may not rent a vehicle until it has been remedied, except for junk automobiles that meet specific criteria. The rental company must comply with limitations on selling, leasing, or renting vehicles within 48 hours of receiving a notice for more than 5,000 vehicles. If a defect remedy is not available, the rental company can temporarily modify the vehicle to eliminate safety risks and continue renting it. The rental company may not rent a vehicle until it has been remedied, except for junk automobiles that meet specific criteria. Vehicle Information System required under section 204 of the Act (49 U.S.C. 30504). SEC. 4. MAKING SAFETY DEVICES AND ELEMENTS INOPERATIVE.

Section 30122(b) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by inserting "rental company," after "dealer," each place such term appears.

SEC. 5. INSPECTIONS, INVESTIGATIONS, AND RECORDS.

Section 30166 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include rental companies in various subsections.

SEC. 6. RESEARCH AUTHORITY. The Secretary of Transportation may conduct a study on the effectiveness of amendments made by this Act and activities of rental companies related to their use and disposition of motor vehicles subject to notification requirements. The Secretary of Transportation may conduct a study on the effectiveness of amendments made by this Act and activities of rental companies related to their use and disposition of motor vehicles subject to notification requirements. Additional requirements include evaluating the completion of safety recall remedies on rental trucks. Reports on these matters are to be submitted as part of the amendment. The Secretary of Transportation will submit a report to congressional committees containing findings of a study on rental companies' handling of motor vehicles subject to safety recall remedies, along with any legislative recommendations deemed necessary. The Secretary of Transportation will seek public comments on the Act's implementation from various stakeholders. The Secretary may create rules to enforce the Act, and the amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
